drupalNodeEvent.title: U.S.-China Climate Cooperation: The Path Forward

field_speakers.processed: Angel Hsu (University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill), Jonas Nahm (Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies), Alex Wang (UCLA Law School)

field_organizers.processed: National Committee on U.S.-China Relations, Penn Center for the Study of Contemporary China

field_description.processed: The United States and China jointly account for 40 percent of global greenhouse emissions, so avoiding the worst consequences of climate change will require collective action by the two countries. In the first program in a series on climate change and the environment, and coinciding with President Bidenâ€™s Leaders Summit on Climate, Professors Angel Hsu, Jonas Nahm, and Alex Wang will discuss the critical importance of U.S.-China climate cooperation at all levels of society, and offer practical proposals for policy action.
